question: Question_01_(e)
statement:
If a function y=f(x) is differentiable at x=3 and
$\displaystyle{}f'(3)=5$, find the limit

\[\lim_{x\to{3}}\frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)}\]
sols:
First of all, both the numerator and denominator converge to zero as
$x\to3$, so we cannot solve the limit directly.

Instead, we need to make use of the fact that $\displaystyle f'(3)=5$.
Taking this as a hint, let's recall the definition of the derivative as
the limit of a difference quotient:

\[f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}\]

For us, \emph{a = 3} and $\displaystyle f'(3) = 5$, so we know the left
hand side of the equation above. To find the limit of the quotient we
are given, let us rewrite our quotient in a similar form as the
difference quotient:

\begin{align*}
\frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &=  x \frac{x-3}{f(3)-f(x)} \\
&= x \left(\frac{f(3)-f(x)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= x \left(\frac{(-1)(f(x)-f(3))}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= x(-1)^{-1} \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= -x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}
\end{align*}

We now recognize the second term as the difference quotient. Hence,
applying the limit laws, we arrive at our final answer

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\to3} \frac{x^2-3x}{f(3)-f(x)} &= \lim_{x\to3} \left[-x \left(\frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1}\right] \\
&= -\left(\lim_{x\to3}x\right) \left(\lim_{x\to3} \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{x-3}\right)^{-1} \\
&= -3 \left(f'(3)\right)^{-1} \\
&=-3 \left(5\right)^{-1} \\
&=-\frac35
\end{align*}

How could you possibly use the fact that $\displaystyle f'(3)=5$ to
solve this limit?
Is there any way to use the definition of the derivative?
